webTitle: Why aerospace and defence are Britain's engines of growth

fields.bodyText: An airport in Hampshire will this week play host to politicians, airline executives and military officials from across the world as the global aerospace and defence industry meets to parade the latest commercial airliners, fighter jets and drones. Welcome to the Farnborough International Airshow 2014 – also a showpiece for British industry, with three of domestic manufacturing's biggest players, Airbus, Rolls-Royce and BAE Systems, displaying their wares. For the public, the two-yearly event is a chance to see the Red Arrows and all the latest commercial and military jets – including, if all goes to plan, the first European flight of the F35-B Lightning II joint strike fighter, which has been grounded since one of the $135m planes caught fire on the runway last month. But the real business of the event, opening on Monday, will take place inside glitzy marquees along the runway, where defence company executives will press the flesh of politicians and army chiefs as they put the finishing touches to billions of pounds' worth of export deals. On the commercial side, airline executives will be wooed by manufacturers Airbus and Boeing, looking for multibillion dollar deals, while Rolls-Royce seeks sales for the engines that power the aircraft. "Everyone wants to get deals done by the next day," says Tom Williams, Airbus executive vice-president and the company's most senior Brit. "Real negotiations are taking place in all those little corridors … it's a very intense week." In 2012, the last time the event was held at Farnborough – it alternates with Paris – more than £42bn of aerospace deals were announced. A similar amount is expect to be pledged this year. A sizable chunk of that cash will find its way to Britain as the UK underlines its prominent role in defence and aerospace, despite spending cuts across the world. For the British aerospace and defence, Farnborough is a shop window. "Aerospace sustains high-value long-term jobs in the UK," says Paul Everitt, chief executive of ADS, the aerospace and defence trade body. "We help create a rich science base with the kind of high-skilled jobs that politicians dream about. Aerospace is unquestionably the Premier League of our manufacturing industries." British defence companies turned over £22bn last year and, importantly to the government's need to rebalance the economy, defence exports amounted to £9.8bn – up 11% on 2012. The UK now accounts for 22% of the global defence export market. Britain's commercial aerospace sector is an even bigger exporter than defence: 90% of the sector's £28bn turnover comes from exports. The UK now accounts for 17% of the global aerospace market – in terms of manufacturing and R&D – and is second only to the US. The industry is also a big employer of highly skilled, well-paid engineers, designers and researchers. More than 100,000 people are directly employed in UK aerospace, with tens of thousands more working indirectly in roles up and down the supply chain. BAE, the UK's largest defence company, employs 34,800 people in Britain: the company claims they generate revenue at a rate of £105,000 per employee – 2.5 times the national average. Importantly for weaning the economy off its reliance on London, the vast majority of defence and aerospace jobs are located outside the capital. BAE assembles the Eurofighter Typhoon in Lancashire and built parts of the new HMS Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier, which the Queen officially named this month, in Glasgow and Portsmouth. Rolls-Royce is another significant British player that will be prominent at Farnborough. It made the engines for the two Royal Navy QE-class aircraft carriers and key engine parts for the F35-B, the Eurofighter Typhoon and the Airbus A400M, which has the world's newest and most powerful propeller engine, as well as the engines for the A380 and the upcoming A350. It, too, is a big UK employer, with 12,000 staff in Derby and 3,500 in Bristol. Despite making some of the noisiest jets in the world, Rolls Royce's Bristol factory is quieter than a City office on a Friday afternoon as engineers methodically go about building and repairing engines that cost millions of pounds each. The quietness is maintained by the use of a double-skinned concrete bunker out the back for engine testing. Engines are also taken to the Sahara and the Arctic circle to check that they can operate at extreme temperatures, while at another facility (dead) Canada geese are fired at engines to check how they cope with bird strikes. At the back of the factory, which has been a Bristol landmark since 1966, white hoardings block off not just visitors but most of the workforce from the section where the lifting system for F35-B jets is being built. The unique technology allows the F35-B – the most expensive military project ever attempted – to hover just feet above the ground, and to land vertically on new aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth. Bristol, which has been famous for engineering since Isambard Kingdom Brunel started building the Clifton suspension bridge in 1829, is a hot spot for UK aerospace. Airbus occupies 12 acres of design and research facilities at what was once Filton airfield – site of the first Concorde flight, in 1969. Franco-German-owned Airbus employs 4,000 people at Filton – designing aircraft, testing landing gear and making wings for the A400M. A further 6,000 Airbus staff are based at Broughton in north Wales, where the wings for the A380 superjumbo are made. Wings for the A400M – made from lightweight composites rather than aluminium to dramatically reduce weight and improve speed and manoeuvrability – are taking shape inside a nondescript hanger in Filton called 07N. Inside, machines that took five years to build and cost €10m each are slowly drilling 12,000 holes into each A400M wing, mainly for attaching covers to the structural ribs and the leading and trailing edges. This kind of painstaking, state-of-the-art work ultimately yields multibillion deals for the likes of Airbus, Rolls-Royce and BAE at Farnborough. John Allen, head of Airbus's component delivery team for wings, explains that the margin for error of the drilling is "plus or minus a thousandth of an inch". Airbus's civilian jets will be the main focus at Farnborough, when it is expected to announce plans to upgrade its widebody A330 jet to be 14% more fuel efficient. The new version, dubbed A330neo, is expected to be powered by a new Rolls-Royce engine that will increase its range by 400 nautical miles. Airbus's Williams, is keeping stumm on the A330 plans and will only say that "a lot of negotiations are still ongoing". Williams says Farnborough has become the focal point for negotiations that may have taken months or even years to hammer out. While many of the deals have been agreed in advance and are saved for announcement at the show, others are "done right up to midnight in conference rooms" and inside Airbus's tent on the Farnborough grounds. He says Farnborough also helps serve as a reminder to the British public that aerospace is one of the last areas of manufacturing at which the UK excels: "The UK is the number two player, beaten only by the US. It's something the UK can be undeniably proud of – lots of other economies around the world look on with envy." He adds that the UK's place at the heart of this global industry is thanks partly to recent political commitment. "The government has been extremely proactive at working with industry to come up with a very significant strategy." Industry and government have pumped £1bn into creating a UK Aerospace Technology Institute as part of the 15-year Aerospace Growth Partnership (AGP) plan. And aerospace is taking a lead in encouraging young people to enter the industry: Airbus runs the biggest apprentice trainee scheme in the country with 450 people signed up in the UK. Williams, who began his career as a Rolls-Royce apprentice, says encouraging young people, and particularly girls, to take more of an interest in science and mathematics is one of his key roles. However, at the Filton plant there is one female apprentice this year (there were none at all last year) and of 45 graduate trainees, just eight are women. A phalanx of government ministers – including business secretary Vince Cable, business minister Michael Fallon, science minister David Willetts and defence secretary Philip Hammond – are due to speak at or attend the show, and David Cameron is expected to put in an appearance on Monday, although the government declined to confirm his attendance because of security concerns. Cable describes UK aerospace as a "global success story" helping to drive the current economic recovery: "Our industrial strategy is ensuring that Britain is well-placed to capitalise on the huge growth anticipated in the aerospace sector, securing highly skilled jobs for the UK and a strong economy." Williams hopes renewed government interest in the sector, and the diversification of Britain's skills base, will help change the public's perceptions of manufacturing and engineers. "People have this perception that industry is all about dark satanic mills with floors covered in dust and dirt," he says. "But when you visit the building where we build the wings [for the A380 in Broughton] you will have to put on a white hat and go inside a giant vacuum cleaner to remove the dirt from you before you'll be allowed in." Next weekend, Farnborough opens to the public, and the government will be hoping that schoolchildren will leave just as impressed as the politicians, airline executives and defence staff.

webTitle: What is the Sports Direct board on?

fields.bodyText: As the UK's former drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell knows a lot about addiction. He took a hard line on hard drugs and, despite being more lenient on cannabis, he resigned when the drug was reclassified as less dangerous. Still, his views on billionaires who might be addicted to trousering ever-expanding pots of wealth look more benign, at least judging from his tenure as chairman of Sports Direct. After three failed efforts by the retailer to satisfy the cravings of founder and largest shareholder Mike Ashley for more shares, Hellawell and his board have finally succeeded in finding a way to give the boss his fix. Earlier this month they pushed through a controversial multimillion-pound bonus scheme – plenty of which will accrue to Ashley, though others will benefit – despite fierce opposition from shareholder lobby groups. We may get a few clues this week about how the firm is limbering up for the start of this scheme – which will kick off next May – when the retailer reports full-year results. Analysts at Jefferies reckon the company and its other shareholders can move on – even though the firm could have chosen to pay all shareholders a dividend. It has never been explained why a plan to hand a few more shares to a man with a 64% stake will be motivational. Sometimes you do wonder what these chaps have been smoking. Laughs are for real in latest Keystone caper Think of the Keystone Cops, the incompetent policemen from early 20th-century silent films, and you might conjure up images of a few comedians arriving at speed to some crisis and immediately falling over. Think of their half-namesake – Gulf Keystone – and you probably think of much the same. The main difference is that the Kurdistan-focused oil company is funny. There will be another screening of some of the company's greatest skits on 17 July when shareholders gather for the annual general meeting. To recap: a year ago, founder Todd Kozel attempted to face down efforts by outside investors to elect four non-executive directors to the board. They included Middle East oil specialist John Bell and former director Jeremy Asher, who had been described as a "disruptive presence" when he last served on the group's board. In true Keystone style they were appointed anyway, only for both to step down last month – when it was also announced that Kozel would retire as chief exec. That news coincided with a 40% hike in the shares, only – again in true Keystone style – they've fallen over again since. Worth watching. Peace's suite of three chairs reduced to two Peace is breaking out at Experian. Well, Sir John Peace is. The group's longstanding chairman – who finds this City lark so effortless that he also has time to chair two other FTSE companies – is finally stepping down from the credit checking group this week, which must represent something of a wrench. Peace spent most of his career at the old retail group Great Universal Stores, where he co-founded what would later become Experian. After becoming GUS's chief executive in 2000, he split the company into three separate listed businesses: the owner of Argos, Home Retail Group; the luxury goods brand Burberry; and Experian. He chaired Burberry as well as Experian. Still, a cut in his workload looks timely. You may have noticed (and can read elsewhere on this page) how he's been having an absolute shocker of a time at Burberry, where he comprehensively misread investors' views about the pay of new chief executive Christopher Bailey. At Standard Chartered, where Peace is also chairman, he has been in similar form: at another damaging rebellion in May, 41% of shareholder votes opposed the bank's pay policy. It seems apt, then, that Peace should now check out of Experian. Its motto? A world of insight.
fields.standfirst: Mike Ashley garners even more shares, plus comedy at Gulf Keystone, and no more Peace at Experian

webTitle: From Obamacare to Marks & Spencer: when websites go wrong

fields.bodyText: The woman in charge of Marks & Spencer's internet presence back in September 2012 was quite sure what was holding back online sales: its website, which had been run for it by Amazon under a deal signed in 2005. The M&S director in question, Laura Wade-Gery, said: "Amazon sells everything as if it was a book. We've tortured their system to do what we want it to do." The retailer began building its own and in February 2014 M&S unveiled a new "magazine-style" site, which drew plaudits from some reviewers. But as well as early reports of crashes, customers apparently felt that there was too much video, that they couldn't find what they wanted, and that the site was "awkward to navigate". So last week M&S knew what to blame for the news that online sales had fallen 8% in three months: its website. Finance director Alan Stewart bravely insisted that "It is a bit like going to the supermarket for milk, they've moved it and you can't find it immediately." But an 8% drop would never happen at an internet business such as Amazon, because it would have spotted it at 1% or 2% and rolled back to a better-performing version. So how can two years of effort by one of Britain's biggest companies produce something that fell so short? According to people in the industry, it is probably because the process took two years. The more monolithic a computer project becomes, the less likely it is to withstand the continual shifts in the way that we use the internet. "For M&S, the fact that it took them 18 to 24 months means whoever did the project planning was two years behind the curve," says David Hamilton of Dog Digital, a media services company that has built websites for private and public sector clients. "In our world, it's about agile development – designing, failing fast, optimising. You don't go for a 'ta-daaaa!' event." The biggest sites, such as Facebook or Amazon, are changing all the time, Hamilton points out – yet they never promote the fact, and the incremental, small nature of the changes makes them hard to spot. But that also means that if a tweak fails – which can easily be measured via statistics such as sales conversions or time spent on the site – then it can be abandoned and the site returned to how it was. It's very often public sector projects that fail badly. Last year, the Obama administration was severely embarrassed when the political triumph of implementing healthcare for all was undermined by a website that crashed repeatedly and suffered security glitches. In the UK, the Department of Work and Pensions' efforts to implement universal credit were so catastrophic that a "tiger team" of programmers was sent in by Francis Maude's Cabinet Office to implement a version that would work for the majority of claimants, rather than trying to cover every case. Yet private sector sites can fail badly too. The canonical example is boo.com, a would-be sports clothing retailer from the first dotcom boom of the 1990s, which built a fabulously complex site able to fulfil orders in a dozen European countries. It offered animations, 360-degree views of clothes and shoes and a virtual shop assistant. But its Swedish founders overlooked the fact that the vast majority of people had dial-up connections and comparatively slow computers – meaning the front page alone could take minutes to load. The company closed after burning through many millions of pounds. The key problem is that the ground has shifted radically since M&S embarked on its change. In September 2012, fewer than 60% of Britons had a smartphone. Now that figure is over 70%. It's no longer just about online shopping, as it was in 2012. Now it's about mobile shopping. Even among the over-55s, more than one in four now own a smartphone and 61% of those people use it to compare prices, according to Kantar researchers. For the young buyer that M&S wants to attract, the focus has shifted from the mobile web to apps – a category that was significantly smaller in 2012. If you're out and you want to order something, you can fire up a store-specific app. While M&S does have an app for iPhone and Android, it has received poor reviews since it was updated in March, with complaints about usability. And who's to say that in another year or two the way that people use their smartphones won't have changed again? Retailers already complain about people "showrooming" – visiting their shops, looking at items and then seeing if they can buy them cheaper online. Amazon is looking to accelerate that with a feature in its new Fire Phone that can identify an object, a picture or a snatch of video via the camera, and show you the item on Amazon – where of course you can order it instantly. "The biggest issue most organisations have is their culture from the boardroom down," says James Stevenson, managing director at digital consultants Bletchley Group. "They specify their requirements, and then one, two or three years later feel pleased they have delivered it only six months late and only 15% over budget. Of course they miss that what has been delivered is already out of date, and no longer what their customers wish." The internet age requires a whole new way of thinking about selling products, says Stevenson. "Too many organisations still think in 'projects', when the reality of business is that these are actually digital products, and need to be managed as such over the lifetime of the digital product." But he sees positive signs inside M&S: "They have started a new way of working and organising themselves, into digital product teams, and are working on being customer-focused and more agile." The company's latest results are the outcome of the old ways, he says. "I'd be optimistic they will see the results of this very soon."
fields.standfirst: M&S's unpopular new site is not the first to damage a firm

In the UK, the Department of Work and Pensions' efforts to implement universal credit were so catastrophic that a "tiger team" of programmers was sent in by Francis Maude's Cabinet Office to implement a version that would work for the majority of claimants, rather than trying to cover every case.

Yet private sector sites can fail badly too. The canonical example is boo.com, a would-be sports clothing retailer from the first dotcom boom of the 1990s, which built a fabulously complex site able to fulfil orders in a dozen European countries. It offered animations, 360-degree views of clothes and shoes and a virtual shop assistant. But its Swedish founders overlooked the fact that the vast majority of people had dial-up connections and comparatively slow computers – meaning the front page alone could take minutes to load. The company closed after burning through many millions of pounds.

The key problem is that the ground has shifted radically since M&S embarked on its change. In September 2012, fewer than 60% of Britons had a smartphone. Now that figure is over 70%. It's no longer just about online shopping, as it was in 2012. Now it's about mobile shopping.

Even among the over-55s, more than one in four now own a smartphone and 61% of those people use it to compare prices, according to Kantar researchers.

For the young buyer that M&S wants to attract, the focus has shifted from the mobile web to apps – a category that was significantly smaller in 2012. If you're out and you want to order something, you can fire up a store-specific app. While M&S does have an app for iPhone and Android, it has received poor reviews since it was updated in March, with complaints about usability.

And who's to say that in another year or two the way that people use their smartphones won't have changed again? Retailers already complain about people "showrooming" – visiting their shops, looking at items and then seeing if they can buy them cheaper online. Amazon is looking to accelerate that with a feature in its new Fire Phone that can identify an object, a picture or a snatch of video via the camera, and show you the item on Amazon – where of course you can order it instantly.

"The biggest issue most organisations have is their culture from the boardroom down," says James Stevenson, managing director at digital consultants Bletchley Group. "They specify their requirements, and then one, two or three years later feel pleased they have delivered it only six months late and only 15% over budget. Of course they miss that what has been delivered is already out of date, and no longer what their customers wish."

The internet age requires a whole new way of thinking about selling products, says Stevenson. "Too many organisations still think in 'projects', when the reality of business is that these are actually digital products, and need to be managed as such over the lifetime of the digital product."

But he sees positive signs inside M&S: "They have started a new way of working and organising themselves, into digital product teams, and are working on being customer-focused and more agile." The company's latest results are the outcome of the old ways, he says. "I'd be optimistic they will see the results of this very soon."
fields.trailText: Charles Arthur: M&S's unpopular new website is not the first to damage a firm

webTitle: The economy was rebalancing. But British exports are losing their drive

fields.standfirst: It is an old complaint but it is still true: UK manufacturers are good at inventing, but bad at bringing technologies to market
fields.body:
One measure of Britain's prowess as a manufacturer can be found in Jaguar Land Rover's 14% year-on-year increase in sales in the first six months of the year.

Forget for a moment that the new Discovery series and Jaguar F-type are driving profits for their foreign owner, India's steel-to-financial-services conglomerate Tata. Concentrate instead on the 240,372 vehicles the company made, the £3.5bn investment planned over the next year, the 28,000 people it employs and the fact the company is one of the UK's largest exporters, generating 85% of its revenue from shipping cars overseas.

The car industry is a top-to-bottom UK industry. From the smallest widget to the finished vehicle, it can all be done in the UK. That many of the parts assembled in Nissan's Washington factory or Honda's Swindon facility come from abroad is not for the lack of parts makers closer to hand.

Britain can say the same in aeroplane manufacturing, pharmaceuticals and food. Beyond these, larger manufacturers tend to supply specialist parts to much bigger businesses in France, Germany or Italy. As such, they have shed low-value processes in favour of niche areas with less competition and more emphasis on quality and long-term relationships.

The industry has changed beyond all recognition from 1996, when it employed 4.2 million people and accounted for more than a fifth of GDP. Today, industry employs 2.6 million and accounts for only 12% of GDP. It is much more efficient – producing as much last year as in 1996 with fewer people – but rarely puts its name on the end product.

There are many who regret the fall in jobs, especially when almost a quarter of Germany's workforce is in manufacturing. Much of the old-style metal-bashing activity associated with manufacturing took place in regions where work is now hard to find. Aluminium smelting once employed thousands, but between 2010 and 2012 the country's last two plants, in Anglesey in Wales and Lynemouth in Northumberland, closed down. High energy costs and impending environmental legislation were blamed, but in truth such plants are dirty and have been chased out of most developed countries.

Economists hoped the financial crisis, which helped wipe out thousands of manufacturing businesses, would at least cut the value of the pound. Since about 45% of all manufactured goods are exported, sterling's value is critical; for more than a decade it was much too high. Suddenly it dropped by a quarter. But in the period after 2009 it seems businesses took the opportunity to raise their prices rather than expand output. And now the currency has regained much of its lost value, we are almost back to square one.

Vince Cable railed against the rising pound last week, while admitting there was little he could do about it. He emphasised the need for investment in productivity, which remains well below pre-crisis levels, with a lack of new machinery and state-of-the-art factories and offices.

But with banks still risk-averse and an overly complex investment tax relief system, there is unlikely to be a great turnaround. The UK's smaller manufacturers are bad at accessing EU funds and keeping up with fast-moving new manufacturing processes.

But those processes could be the industry's saviour. Codified and computerised systems allow several stages to be condensed into one, potentially saving millions. Without funding and the know-how inside government and its many agencies to spot serious contenders, new designs coming out of universities and research institutions will be snapped up by foreigners.

It is an age-old problem. We are good at inventing but bad at investing, developing and bringing to market.

The Royal Mail sell-off is under review. Now for an apology

For the past nine months the business secretary, Vince Cable, has repeatedly refused to apologise for his handling of the privatisation of Royal Mail, which MPs concluded last week had been flogged off on the cheap, leaving taxpayers £1bn out of pocket.

He dismissed the 38% first-day surge in the share price – the biggest one-day rise in a privatisation since British Airways in 1987 – as "froth and speculation". But rather than settling down, as Cable suggested they would, the shares continued to rise, eventually reaching 618p. They did fall back to 476p on Friday, but are still 44% above the 330p offer price.

But Cable insists on calling the sale a success. "The point we have stressed, and I've stressed over and over again, is that the price of shares is very, very volatile – these things go up and down and we've seen in the past few weeks the price of Royal Mail shares actually falling like a stone."

Critics, Cable has said, have the benefit of hindsight. Perhaps he has forgotten that in the weeks before the float, analysts were queueing up to warn that 330p was far too low. Some banks suggested a value as high as 510p.

One bank, however, was far more cautious: Lazard & Co, the government's adviser on the float, which suggested selling the shares as cheaply as 212p and warned Cable that if he increased the price above 330p, the blue chip institutional investors he desperately wanted to buy in would balk.

One of the biggest buyers was Lazard Asset Management (LAM), to whom Cable gave "golden ticket" status, allowing it to buy 6m shares at 330p. Within 48 hours LAM sold all its shares at 470p, to reap a profit of £8.4m.

There was still no apology, but last week Cable announced an "informal review" of how the government handles privatisations. Lord Myners, a City grandee and former financial services secretary, will lead this review. Myners, who is far from averse to straight talking, should force an apology, if not a resignation, out of Cable.

M&S's bean counter might help Tesco, but only a little

So Alan Stewart is to swap his Paddington des res for the Soviet-era chic of Tesco House in Cheshunt. The finance director's surprise defection from M&S to Britain's biggest supermarket comes at an awkward time for both retailers as their respective chief executives effect glacially slow turnarounds. But Tesco was supposed to be hiring a world-beater after a boardroom clearout that left Philip Clarke as the last executive standing, and it is hard to see what convinced the grocery chain that Stewart was the bean counter for them.

His predecessor, Laurie McIlwee, was castigated for shoddy forecasting yet on Stewart's watch M&S's margin guidance was a movable feast. He is credited with helping Kate Swann make a silk purse out of a sow's ear at WH Smith and at M&S he was an able translator of Marc Bolland's opaque pronouncements, but it is difficult to argue that he put a stamp on the business. It remains to be seen whether he and Clarke will speak the same language.

webTitle: Tobacco giant 'tried blackmail' to block Ugandan anti-smoking law

fields.bodyText: One of Britain's biggest companies has been accused of "blackmail" by a Ugandan MP spearheading tough new anti-smoking laws in his country. British American Tobacco, in conjunction with other leading tobacco companies, is using its considerable financial clout to oppose Dr Chris Baryomunsi's private member's bill aimed at curbing smoking in a country where cigarettes kill 13,500 people a year. Anti-tobacco campaigners see the bill as a watershed moment with significant consequences for cigarette companies. Enó Isong, associate director, International Communications Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, said European tobacco companies could not countenance a decrease in smoking rates in Africa. "Most western countries have put in place policies to blunt the tobacco industry," he said. "It is very clear that the tobacco industry is shifting its market to Africa – a young market where they can bully their way around." In a letter to Baryomunsi, BAT Uganda confirmed that it will no longer do business with the 709 farmers in his Kihihi constituency that it normally buys from because his bill – and a related plan to raise tobacco taxes – has rendered the arrangement "increasingly less economically viable". BAT, which has a stock market valuation of $65bn, buys tobacco from 18,000 farmers in Uganda and Baryomunsi said he was under no illusions about why the company had targeted the farmers in his district first. "Although they said it was a business decision, the reason was merely blackmail," Baryomunsi said. "They thought that the farmers would rise against me and disorganise me politically, but I told them I was not moved. I actually assured them that what mattered to me was not the number of years I spend in parliament but what I do when in parliament. I assured them that no amount of blackmail and intimidation would shake me." Baryomunsi's bill will impose large health warnings covering 75% of the face of cigarette packets, bar smoking within 100 metres of public buildings, prohibit advertising, ban point of sale display marketing, raise the smoking age from 18 to 21 and limit interaction between the government and tobacco lobby. But tobacco farmers' groups, backed by tobacco lobbyists, have reacted with fury to the plans, claiming the measures will put them out of business. Documents seen by the Observer show that BAT has mounted a heavy lobbying campaign, warning MPs on the country's health committee that replacing the existing Tobacco Act threatens the livelihoods of thousands of farmers. "Currently an estimated 60,000 farmers grow tobacco in Uganda under the sponsorship of licensed tobacco companies which are obliged to purchase the crop, hence providing a ready market," the company warns them in a letter. "Repeal of the Tobacco (Control and Marketing) Act and Regulations would not only threaten the livelihood of these farmers but also the revenues generated and investments made in this part of the sector by tobacco companies." In March, Senegal introduced new anti-smoking legislation and Baryomunsi predicted other African countries would soon follow suit. "My bill is quite comprehensive and once passed will revolutionalise the fight against tobacco in Africa," Baryomunsi said. "The bill has the support of Ugandans. It is only the [tobacco] industry that is spearheading this opposition voice. There are some provisions that have attracted debate, maybe I will concede on some of the proposals in the bill, but definitely the bill will have to pass without being severely watered down." Rachel Rose Jackson, of the tobacco tactics team at the Tobacco Control Research Group at the University of Bath, accused BAT of double standards. "BAT wants us to believe that it is acting responsibly and transparently and it repeats this message to the public over and over again. In fact, the company is acting in violation of its mandates and international codes and regulations. In Uganda, some of BAT's activities include actively trying to attract children and women to its products; using its political influence and economic power behind the scenes to stall tobacco legislation; and fostering a system of credit bondage whereby tobacco farmers are continually indebted to the company." BAT rejected the accusations and said that it was acting legitimately to defend the livelihood of farmers. "It can't be underestimated how important tobacco growing is to farmers in Uganda," the company said in a statement. "Many depend on tobacco growing to feed and house their families, and pay for children to attend school. If Ugandan tobacco leaf becomes uncompetitive abroad, we have to look at other options. Regrettably, the uncertainty in Uganda, which may make it unnecessarily costly for us to source tobacco from there, has forced us to review our tobacco growing operations in Kihihi."

webTitle: Pizza Express sells for £900m to Chinese investment group

fields.standfirst: Hony Capital wins British restaurant chain at auction in biggest European restaurant sector deal in last five years
fields.body:
Pizza Express has been bought for £900m by a Chinese firm which plans to roll out the British restaurant chain in the world's most populous country.

Hony Capital won an auction process ahead of Citic, another Chinese investment group, and four other private equity firms in what is the biggest European restaurant sector deal in the last five years.

Pizza Express opened its first outlet in Beijing two months ago. It already has 12 restaurants in Hong Kong and nine in Shanghai.

The Pizza Express chief executive, Richard Hodgson, said the sale was a positive development for the 504-outlet chain: "Asia is a key part of our future growth strategy and Hony's expertise in this region will be invaluable. We are looking forward to working with them on this as well as our ambitious UK growth plans."

Hodgson and the management team will remain with the business following the deal.

Hony Capital's chief executive, John Zhao, said he was pleased to acquire what he described as a well-established and exciting brand.

"With PizzaExpress, we have the opportunity to leverage our local expertise to accelerate its growth in the Chinese market, as well as to continue to drive its business forward in the UK," he said.

The company aims to open another 200 restaurants in the UK.

The chain, which was founded in Soho, central London, in 1965, has changed hands several times, with Cinven buying it for £1bn at the end of 2006 shortly before the financial crash. The company fell to a pre-tax loss of £79m after £110m of interest payments on its £1.2bn debt mountain, despite a 4.2% rise in Pizza Express total sales to £604.2m for the year to 30 June 2013. It employs 9,000 people worldwide.

The chain was owned between 1993 and 1999 by the entrepreneur Luke Johnson, a former Channel 4 and Royal Society of the Arts chairman, along with Hugh Osmond. During that time it expanded from 12 outlets in the UK to more than 250.

Pizza Express was the biggest asset in the Cinven-owned Gondala Group, which includes other "fast casual" chains Zizzi and ASK Italian. It sold the posh burger chain Byron to Hutton Collins in October 2013 for £100m and will now explore options for offloading its remaining two chains.
